_prev_prog_3.Description: Stevco Cold Storage has prepared a unified Risk & Process Safety Management Program.  The program is in compliance with California's Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program (in California CCR Title 19, Chapter 4.5 Program Level 3 Elements.  At the Federal level, Title 40 CFR Part 68), and California OSHA's "Process Safety Management (PSM) of Acutely Hazardous Materials" standard (in California CCR Title 8, Section 5189, "Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials," and Federally Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119).  This program has been prepared to address the risks involved with the presence of anhydrous ammonia in an amount in excess of 10,000 lbs., which is contained in our refrigeration system.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMPPSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Grapeman Bakersfield Cold Storage LP has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities.



1.1 Grapeman Bakersfield Cold Storage LP, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Grapeman Bakersfield Cold Storage LP has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities:



Process Name                            

Ammonia Refrigeration



Process Chemical

Anhydrous Ammonia 



Process Quantity(lbs.)

56,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have:



1. Prepared a unified progra

m based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant

information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Description



The Stevco Cold Storage facility is a commercial cold storage facility for table grapes. The facility has an ammonia system that provides refrigeration capacity to six (6) precool rooms, ten (10) cold storage rooms, a repack room, and a shipping area. The precool and cold storage rooms utilize bunker mounted evaporators while the repack room and shipping area utilized ceiling suspended evaporators. A computer system provides substantial control and alarm capability.



The system operates as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receivers is piped to each flooded zone of refrigeration, where it passes through a solenoid valve, an expansion valve, and into a low temperature & pressure accumulator vessel mounted on the roof. From the accumulators, cold liquid ammonia is circulated through evaporator coils. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature & pressure gas which is returned to the accumulator vessels. The ammonia vapor is returned from the accumulator vessels through a suction return line to our main suction accumulator in the engine room. From there, it passes through the compressors. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to a thermosyphon vessel and from the thermosyphon vessel it returns to the high pressure receiver. High pressure liquid from the thermosyphon vessel is supplied to the oil coolers on each screw compressor. High temperature liquid is evaporate

d in the oil cooler and a combination of high temperature gas and liquid is returned to the thermosyphon vessel by thermosyphon action. Liquid separated from the suction return gas in the main suction accumulator drains into the liquid transfer vessel. Operation of a float switch activated solenoid valve raises the pressure in the liquid transfer vessels to the point the liquid can be drained into the high pressure receivers. There are three high pressure receivers, however, they are piped together so that they act in concert.



The facility was originally built in 2000. More recently the following projects have occurred:

- 2001 California Controlled Atmosphere supplied and installed the refrigeration equipment for Phase 2

- 2006 California Controlled Atmosphere supplied and installed the refrigeration equipment for Phase 3

- 2008 California Controlled Atmosphere supplied and installed the refrigeration equipment for the

Repack Room



All of the different phases were built in compliance with the Uniform Mechanical Code and Uniform Building Code applicable at the time of construction. The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and safety relief valves which vent ammonia gas to a water diffusion tank if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point. In addition, ammonia detectors are located throughout the facility, and will shut down equipment if ammonia is detected. Lastly, an emergency "dump box" contains switches and valves to turn off equipment and vent ammonia if necessary.



The ammonia system at this facility consists of vessels which are interconnected, or which are colocated such that a release of ammonia could impact the ability to operate vessels that are not directly connected. Therefore, the facility is treated as a single process.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General



We inform

our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Grapeman Bakersfield Cold Storage LP has also conducted an offsite consequence analysis of worst case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders.



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Grapeman Bakersfield Cold Storage LP facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active logbook of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment.



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Grapeman Bakersfield Cold Storage LP has had one (1) accidental release within the last five (5) years.

1. Incident Investigation # 201202

 a. October 24, 2012 | Accident Duration: 30 min

 b. Regulated Substance Released: Aqueous Ammonia

 c. Quantity Released: Negligible

 d. NAICS: 115114

 e. Aqueous Ammonia release from an AutoPurger

 f. Weather Conditions: Unknown

 g. Onsite Impacts: 2 injuries

 h. Known offsite impacts: None

 i. Initiating event and contributing factors:

    1. Two employees were preparing to clean the bubbler on the Auto Purger in the engi

ne room when it over-pressurized, rupturing from the bottom and spraying bothof them with aqueous ammonia. Contributing factors included over-pressurization due to a) mineral deposits found in the drain line b) the 3 inch plug on top of the Bubbler "was very tight; manufacturer recommendation is to 'keep plug lubricated and hand tight'" and The Auto Purger was running when work was being performed on the bubbler.

 j. Offsite Responders: Notified and Responded

 k. Recommendations: training on operating procedures for AutoPurger



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Grapeman Bakersfield Cold Storage LP's emergency action and response program has been developed to

satisfy the following requirements:

- California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- Federal "Emergency Action Plan" Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

- California "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 ?5192(q)

- Federal "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR ?1910.120(q)



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Grapeman Bakersfield Cold Storage LP has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Grapeman Bakersfield Cold Storage LP continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMPPSM program. This has improved Grapeman Bakersfield Cold Storage LP's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMPPSM related events so that Grapeman Bakersfield Cold Storage LP's management team can ensure that the RMPPSM program is being implemented.



Grapeman Bakersfield Cold Storage LP has implemented all aspects of the RMPPSM program. When a RMP-PSM prog

ram requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible  person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using  PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Grapeman Bakersfield Cold Storage LP has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Grapeman Bakersfield Cold Storage LP now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Grapeman Bakersfield Cold Storage LP employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Grapeman Bakersfield  Cold Storage LP will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
